Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Developing Effective Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary Interventions to Prevent Intimate Partner Violence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: Significant resources have been expended to provide services to intimate partner violence (IPV) victims and to increase perpetrator accountability through criminal justice interventions, but less attention has been given to preventing IPV. The 2-day Workshop to Develop Effective Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary Interventions to Prevent Intimate Partner Violence will bring together researchers, practitioners, advocates, and students from various fields (social sciences, law, public health, medicine, victim services and advocacy) to critically examine IPV prevention at three levels: programs to stop IPV from occurring (primary prevention), methods to reduce the consequences of IPV when it occurs (secondary prevention), and programs to respond to victims and perpetrators to prevent IPV reoccurrence (tertiary prevention). Participants will: 1) identify knowledge gaps at all three levels of prevention; 2) examine findings from current evaluations of promising programs, especially those designed for underserved groups; 3) develop recommendations for future research; 4) foster interdisciplinary collaboration to develop new research projects; and 5) promote mentoring relationships among researchers, graduate students, practitioners, and advocates. To achieve these goals, participants will either: a) prepare a paper evaluating current knowledge and practices for a type of IPV prevention; b) discuss knowledge or practices gaps in IVP prevention; c) prepare a paper on evaluation outcomes for a type of prevention; or d) facilitate discussion of the next generation of prevention research. Workshop activities will produce knowledge useful to researchers, practitioners, advocates and students throughout the United States and internationally to develop innovative prevention programs, especially for underserved communities. The materials produced (i.e., reports, an edited book, a website) will also be useful to policy makers and other stakeholders as they work to address the problem of IPV.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Workshop: Developing Effective Primary, Secondary and Tertiary Interventions to Prevent Intimate Partner Violence (IPV) brought together an interdisciplinary group of researchers, practitioners, and students to critically examine strategies for preventing IPV from occurring (primary prevention), methods for ameliorating the short- and long-term consequences of IPV once it occurs (secondary prevention), and innovative programs to respond to both victims and perpetrators to prevent IPV from reoccurring (tertiary prevention). Over a two-day period, workshop participants: 1) shared research findings from current evaluations of promising, innovative interventions at all three levels of prevention, particularly those designed to reach underserved and marginalized populations (e.g., immigrants and refugees, racial and ethnic minorities, trafficked or sexually exploited women and girls, and members of LGBTQ communities); 2) identified gaps in knowledge with regard to all three levels of IPV prevention; and 3) made recommendations for future research and practice innovations on all three levels of prevention.

Specific topics addressed at the workshop included: primary prevention in educational settings, including K-12 and college, with particular focus on bystander intervention programming; how to effectively engage men and boys in IPV prevention; how to effectively screen for IPV in formal and informal settings, particularly health care settings; alternatives to the criminalization of IPV, such as restorative justice programs, as tertiary prevention strategies; how IPV victims conceptualize justice; tertiary prevention programs for women who use violence in intimate relationships; the use of horticultural therapy as tertiary prevention in a shelter for battered women; and developing a research agenda to fill gaps in IPV knowledge and practice.

In addition to the intellectual tasks that engaged workshop participants, the format--working in teams of 2-3 members from different disciplines, occupations, career stages, and backgrounds--fostered interdisciplinary networking and collaborations for the development of research to fill the knowledge and practice gaps that were identified. Moreover, mentoring relationships developed across disciplines between junior and senior researchers, faculty and graduate students, and researchers and practitioners. These are expected to produce partnerships for continued collaboration on IPV prevention projects at all three levels. Indeed, to our knowledge, this is the first workshop to address all three levels of prevention through interdisciplinary and researcher-practitioner collaboration. Workshop teams are currently co-authoring chapters based on workshop presentations and discussions for an edited collection on the major prevention topics that were addressed.

A full report on the workshop that includes the two-day agenda, background for the development of the workshop process and topics, and summaries of the presentations and discussions is available at http://uknowledge.uky.edu/ipv/. Abstracts for chapters to be included in the edtied collection of papers from the workshop are also available on this site.
